an8.10:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Campā on the banks of the Gaggarā Lotus Pond.
an8.10:1.2: Now at that time the mendicants accused a mendicant of an offense.
an8.10:1.3: The accused mendicant dodged the issue, distracted the discussion with irrelevant points, and displayed annoyance, hate, and bitterness.
an8.10:2.1: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants,
an8.10:2.4: This person should be shown the door.
an8.10:2.5: Why should you be vexed by an outsider?
an8.10:2.6: Take a case where a certain person looks just the same as other good-natured mendicants when going out and coming back, when looking ahead and aside, when bending and extending the limbs, and when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes.
an8.10:2.7: That is, so long as the mendicants don’t notice his offense.
an8.10:2.8: But when the mendicants notice the offense, they know that he’s
an8.10:2.9: a corrupt ascetic, just useless trash.
an8.10:2.10: When they realize this they send him away.
an8.10:2.12: So that he doesn’t corrupt good-natured mendicants.

an8.10:5.1: Suppose that a large heap of grain is being winnowed. The grains that are firm and substantial form a heap on one side. And the grains that are flimsy and insubstantial are blown over to the other side.
an8.10:5.2: Then the owners take a broom and sweep them even further away.
an8.10:5.4: So that it doesn’t spoil the good grain.

an8.10:6.1: Suppose a man needs an irrigation gutter for a well. He’d take a sharp axe and enter the wood,
an8.10:6.2: where he’d knock various trees with the axe. The trees that were firm and substantial made a cracking sound.
an8.10:6.3: But the trees that were rotten inside, decomposing and decayed, made a thud.
an8.10:6.4: He’d cut down such a tree at the root, lop off the crown, and thoroughly clear out the insides. Then he’d use it as an irrigation gutter for the well.
an8.10:6.5: In the same way, take a case where a certain person looks just the same as other good-natured mendicants when going out and coming back, when looking ahead and aside, when bending and extending the limbs, and when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes.
an8.10:6.6: That is, so long as the mendicants don’t notice his offense.

an8.10:6.8: a corrupt ascetic, just useless trash.
an8.10:6.9: When they realize this they send him away.

an8.10:8.1: They speak to people with a voice
an8.10:8.2: so smooth, just like an ascetic.
an8.10:8.3: But they act in secret, with their bad views
an8.10:8.4: and their lack of regard for others.
